title: Performance Review Anxiety Tax
context: Annual performance reviews are supposed to drive performance — set expectations, provide feedback, calibrate compensation. But the annual review cycle creates a persistent anxiety tax on the organization. For weeks before reviews, productivity drops as employees curate their self-assessments, managers write reviews, and calibration meetings consume leadership time. The review itself is a high-stakes, low-information event: a year of work compressed into a rating that determines compensation and career trajectory. Recency bias dominates — the last 2 months matter more than the first 10. Employees optimize for review visibility rather than actual impact. The anxiety peaks during calibration, where managers horse-trade ratings in a zero-sum game. The process that was supposed to improve performance instead creates a quarterly cycle of anxiety, political behavior, and productivity loss.
hypothesis: Annual performance reviews drive accountability and improve performance.

effects.impact: 2-4 weeks of reduced output per cycle

dontIf: Your review process takes more than 2 weeks of organizational time
Feedback is only given during the annual review cycle
ifYouMust: Supplement annual reviews with continuous feedback mechanisms
Require managers to document feedback throughout the year, not just at review time
Separate development conversations from compensation decisions
Use calibration to check for bias, not to force-rank employees

alternatives.name: Continuous feedback
alternatives.note: Regular 1:1s with real-time feedback replace annual review

alternatives.name: Quarterly lightweight check-ins
alternatives.note: Brief quarterly reviews reduce recency bias and anxiety
